messages.content: Eh bro, you really wake up at 0500 every day ah?
Affirmative. As an officer cadet, discipline starts the moment I open my eyes. 0500 means 0450, because being on time is already late.
Wah lao eh, even weekends also?
Yes, even weekends. The standard doesn’t rest just because it’s Sunday. Cadet Wing maintains consistency across all days. Bearing must never drop.
You not tired meh, everyday like that.
Negative, I am fully operational… though internally collapsing. But mission success is paramount. Fatigue is weakness leaving the body.
You sure PC not watching you now?
Bro, assume PC is always watching. Wayang is not an act—it’s a lifestyle. Leadership by example, at all times.
Why you always walk so fast one sia?
As a cadet, I move with purpose. There is no strolling in OCS. Every step is a statement of readiness.
But the cookhouse only like 200m away leh.
Even more reason to get there efficiently. Momentum and urgency reflect internal discipline. Later PC see you strolling, confirm tekan.
You never slack one meh?
Negative. Slackness is contagious. I must embody the leadership values taught to us. Integrity, discipline, and bearing must be maintained—even when nobody’s watching.
Wah okay lah, I just walk slowly behind you then.
Noted, but I advise otherwise. Move fast, look sharp, act confident. Cadet Wing must set the example for all.
Why your boots always so shiny one sia?
Boots reflect the soul, bro. A clean boot shows a clean mindset. Every night, even if I fall asleep standing, I still polish before lights out.
But no one even checks what.
Doesn’t matter. We don’t do it for the checks—we do it for the standard. Self-discipline means doing the right thing even when unobserved.
But sometimes I just too shag man.
Understandable. But as future officers, we cannot give in to fatigue. One shiny boot today leads to mission success tomorrow.
Aiyo you sound like instructor sia.
Take it as a compliment. If I can emulate the standards of our instructors, I know I’m on the right path to commissioning.
How many push-ups you can do now ah?
Currently, 80 proper form push-ups under fatigue conditions. But it’s not about the number—it’s about consistency and form. Every rep counts.
What you mean by 'under fatigue'?
Under fatigue means after a 12km route march, zero rest, and full battle order. Officer Cadets don’t train in comfort. We fight tired because we lead tired men.
That one sound damn siong leh.
It is. But mental strength must exceed physical exhaustion. Outfield train body, but also train heart and mind.
You not scared collapse ah?
Fear is natural. But I control it. I owe it to my platoon and to the mission. Pain is temporary—failure to lead is forever.
You all go outfield how long never bathe ah?
Longest was 7 days, no shower. Just powder bath and face wipe. Hygiene discipline still enforced—just no luxury.
Wah confirm smell like jungle.
Affirmative. But everyone same smell, so we adapt. Smell is temporary—mission success is eternal.
You never complain meh?
Complaints reduce morale. Leadership requires us to absorb hardship and still smile. Even if inside dying, outside must garang.
Respect sia, I cannot tahan 2 days already.
You’ll be surprised what you can endure when the platoon is counting on you. It’s not about individual comfort—it’s about collective mission success.
You all really pack full field pack every time ah?
Yes, standard load. Even if not used, must bring. It’s about readiness. An officer doesn’t gamble with preparedness.
But so heavy, why not leave behind?
That’s a mindset issue. Mission dictates equipment. Personal comfort is secondary to operational readiness.
You got everything memorised already right?
Affirmative. Standard packing list is muscle memory now. I can pack blindfolded, in the dark, under time pressure.
You really take this seriously sia.
Because lives depend on it. Even in training, we simulate the real thing. Leadership means no shortcuts.
Why your beret wear until like parade one sia?
Because presentation reflects pride. Every time I don the beret, I remind myself I’m representing the Officer Corps.
But just normal training day leh.
There are no 'normal' days in OCS. Every day is an opportunity to lead by example. Bearing must not fluctuate with routine.
Later sweat until messy again.
Then I adjust again. Sweat is part of the job. But standards must be restored at every opportunity.
You iron your uniform also ah?
Every night. Creased uniform, creased mind. Neatness breeds clarity.
Why you salute the OC so loud one?
Because respect is not negotiable. When I salute, I do it with full force. Officer Cadets must show they understand military bearing.
Like scare him sia.
If it startles him, then my salute worked. Confidence, presence, and commitment must come across in every gesture.
You shout like parade square also.
That’s the standard. Half-hearted efforts reflect poorly on Cadet Wing. Everything we do must reflect the Corps values.
One day you lose voice I not surprised.
Losing voice is acceptable. Losing pride in our conduct is not.
You guys really no phones during field camp?
Affirmative. Phones remain in Wingline. Total focus is on the training and the mission. Distractions cost lives.
So how you tahan?
We adapt. Brotherhood replaces notifications. Mission objectives replace scrolling. It's liberating, actually.
Don't miss family meh?
Of course I do. But I channel that into performance. The best way to honour them is to commission strong.
Damn, got respect for you guys lah.
Appreciated. But it's not about glory—it's about responsibility. Every cadet is trained to lead with heart and discipline.
You all really never sit down during SDO duty?
Correct. Duty Officer posture must reflect alertness. Sitting is a privilege we forgo while standing watch.
But overnight shift leh bro.
No excuse. If I show fatigue, what message do I send to my men? Leadership is about maintaining presence under pressure.
Even when no one see?
Especially when no one sees. That’s integrity. That’s OCS.
You sleep how many hours sia?
Between 3 to 5 hours average. But energy is drawn from purpose, not sleep. Mission readiness always comes first.
OCS got aircon bunk or not?
Negative. Only ceiling fan and ventilation. Comfort is not a priority in leadership training. We train to endure, not to enjoy.
But y’all officer what, don’t need standard?
Standard starts from discomfort. If I cannot tahan heat in peacetime, how to command in combat? Mental strength comes from hardship.
You sweat until cannot sleep how?
Then I sweat and still sleep. Adaptation is part of the process. We don’t complain, we condition ourselves.
I confirm KO in 2 days there.
You’d be surprised what you can handle when you’ve got a platoon depending on you. We don’t train individuals—we train leaders.
How you all remember so many mission briefs one sia?
Repetition, practice, and sheer will. We rehearse until it becomes instinct. As officer cadets, we cannot afford mental blanks during ops.
But sometimes PC suddenly ask then blank out how?
Then you recover fast, answer confidently, even if dying inside. Composure under pressure is what separates leaders from followers.
Don’t dare make eye contact with PC sia.
That’s why we train. PC pressure now builds resistance later. Embrace the heat—because one day, you'll be the one giving the orders.
Still scary lah.
Fear is expected. But leadership means taking action despite fear. That’s what OCS teaches us.
You all go canteen like booking out sia, why so formal?
Because even off the parade square, we uphold standards. Uniform neat, bearing on, movement with purpose. Public sees cadets—they must see excellence.
But just want to eat only leh bro.
Eating is not an excuse to slack. We lead by example 24/7. Relaxing does not mean letting go of professionalism.
You not paiseh ah, everyone stare?
They stare because they notice the difference. That difference is what OCS instills. Presence is part of leadership.
Respect lah. I wear slippers confirm kena already.
Correct. Discipline isn’t just for show—it’s who we are. Even a simple meal reflects our training.
Outfield you all sleep inside basha or just lie on ground?
Basha is mandatory. Even if it rains sideways or the ground is mud. It’s about protection, discipline, and preparedness.
But sometimes faster just lie down right?
Shortcut today, regret tomorrow. As officers, we enforce standards, not shortcuts. A collapsed basha at 0200 is a leadership failure.
Confirm shag, set up then break down.
Shag is expected. But we move regardless. Every action is training for command—if I can’t handle this, I can't handle troops.
You all different breed man.
Not different—just trained to lead. And we take that seriously, every single day.
Got time to gym in OCS or not?
Limited, but we make it work. PT slots, admin time, or even before first parade—we find windows to maintain fitness.
I thought training already shag enough?
Yes, but physical excellence is part of the standard. No excuses. A fit leader inspires confidence.
So you gym after route march also?
If operationally feasible, yes. It’s not about the body—it’s about the mindset. Always pushing the limit.
Can see your arms bigger already sia.
Appreciate the observation. But the real goal is not biceps—it’s battle readiness and functional strength.
How come you all shout so loud during parade?
Because parade is a showcase of discipline and morale. Our voice must carry authority, confidence, and pride.
Don’t your throat spoil after that?
Temporarily, yes. But voice can recover. Reputation and bearing? That must never falter.
You shout louder than the PC sometimes.
Not my intention to outshine, but to match the energy. Presence must be felt—even before words are spoken.
Wah, steady lah you.
Not steady—just trained. Parade isn’t just a show, it’s a statement of unity and discipline.
OCS got time to study for uni or not?
Negative. OCS is full-time commitment. Focus is on leadership, not academics. We study tactics, not textbooks.
So you never touch books at all ah?
Only doctrine and ops manuals. Academic books take a backseat until commissioning. Right now, my priority is the platoon.
You not worried you forget everything?
That’s a risk, but temporary. Leadership training now builds a mindset that will help in anything later.
You sound very motivated sia.
Not motivated—committed. Motivation fades. Commitment sustains.
How you tahan tekan from instructors sia?
By focusing on growth, not pain. Every tekan is a chance to improve. They tekan because they care about our development.
But sometimes feel like personal attack leh.
Understandable feeling. But we must depersonalise it. They’re training the leader in us, not punishing the person.
Don’t feel like giving up meh?
Many times. But giving up is a luxury we can’t afford. Future soldiers deserve leaders who’ve pushed through hardship.
You got my respect lah bro.
Thank you. But I’m just a cadet trying to earn my rank the right way.
You all eat so fast, can even taste food or not?
Barely. But we’re not there for fine dining. Meal time is fuel stop—quick, clean, and efficient.
Don’t you get indigestion?
Stomach adapt already. Fast eating is part of time management. Every second saved is one more for admin prep.
You can finish in like 5 minutes sia.
Correct. 5 minutes in, then 55 minutes for packing, uniform, rehearsals. Priorities, bro.
Food good or not at least?
It’s sufficient. Nutrition is more important than taste. Satisfaction comes from performance, not seasoning.
What if you fall sick during training?
If it’s minor, I push through. Serious cases, report to MO. But the first instinct is always to continue unless operationally unfit.
Not scared kena scolding?
Scolding is part of training. Health must be preserved for the mission. But malingering? That’s dishonourable.
So you kena fever you still move?
Happened before. Paracetamol, hydrate, press on. Because the mission doesn’t pause for my temperature.
Wah, you all different level sia.
We’re trained to lead from the front. If I fall, I get up. That’s what’s expected of an officer cadet.
What if you really cannot complete the route march?
Then you keep moving until safety is at risk. Quitting is not an option unless medically necessary. Every step is one closer to mental toughness.
But what if legs cramp halfway?
Hydrate, stretch, push. If I collapse, then medical will intervene. But I never decide to stop on my own. That’s the mindset drilled into us.
Got people drop before or not?
Yes. It happens. But we recover, rejoin, and never give up. OCS teaches us how to fall and rise.
Wah, no joke sia.
Negative. This is preparation for leadership under stress. If route march scare me, combat operations how?
Why you all keep shouting ‘training to lead’ everywhere?
Because it's more than a motto—it’s a commitment. Every time we say it, we reinforce our purpose. It keeps morale and focus sharp.
Like brainwash sia.
Some call it brainwash. We call it instilling values. In the field, when morale drops, these words remind us why we’re here.
So no one slacks off?
We hold each other accountable. One weak link affects the whole platoon. That’s why we say it loud—so everyone hears and feels it.
Makes sense lah.
Affirmative. Spirit and discipline must be enforced from within, not just top-down.
So how you prepare for stand-by bunk inspection?
We start prep the moment we step into the bunk. Bed tight, floor spotless, uniform aligned, everything at right angles. Precision is key.
Don’t they always find something wrong anyway?
Correct. They’re not looking for perfection—they’re looking for effort and discipline. The standard must be chased, even if never reached.
What’s the worst you kena?
Toothbrush not aligned with mug. Lost 30 minutes admin time. Lesson learnt: small things reflect big mindset.
Wah serious sia.
Every detail counts. If I miss my toothbrush, what else might I miss on the battlefield?
How you all cope with lack of sleep?
We condition our bodies and minds. Naps during admin time, caffeine only if last resort. Mostly, it’s mindset. Sleep is a luxury—not a necessity here.
But won’t affect performance?
That’s why we train tired. Because in ops, there’s no 8-hour sleep. We must lead tired, hungry, cold—and still succeed.
You ever hallucinate before?
Came close. Saw a vending machine in the jungle once. But I pressed on. Reality is discipline in action.
That one confirm shag.
Shag is standard. Garang is the expectation.
How’s your relationship with your buddy?
Strong. Buddy system is lifeline in OCS. We cover each other’s blind spots, physically and mentally. Mission first, buddy always.
What if your buddy slacks?
Then I pull him up. I don’t throw shade—I lead him back on track. Leadership starts with the man beside you.
You ever argue with him before?
Of course. Stress brings friction. But we resolve fast—because ops won’t wait for our feelings to settle.
Real brotherhood sia.
Exactly. Brotherhood forged through sweat, rain, and tekan never breaks easily.
You all so serious, still got time to laugh or not?
Affirmative. Humour is survival. We joke in the mud, we laugh during rations. It keeps morale high—but never at the expense of discipline.
Instructors allow that ah?
If it’s controlled and doesn’t disrupt training, yes. They know we’re human. But once it’s time to lock in, switch must flip instantly.
What kind of jokes you all crack?
Mostly about how shag we are, or how everything is ‘character building’. Shared suffering builds inside jokes fast.
Haha steady lah.
Laughter is fuel. But standards still apply. Joy doesn’t mean slack.
What if you kena tekan for something your section never do?
Then we absorb. OCS teaches collective responsibility. As future officers, we own the outcome—good or bad.
But won’t feel unfair meh?
Fairness is not the point. Leadership is. The men we lead won’t care who messed up—they care who steps up.
Still very hard leh.
Exactly. That’s why we’re trained this way. If it were easy, everyone would wear the bar.
Respect, bro.
Appreciate it. Just trying to earn it the right way.
You guys really clean rifle every night?
Without fail. Rifle is part of us. Clean weapon, clear conscience. Doesn’t matter how tired—never sleep with dirty weapon.
But just blank rounds only right?
Still carbon residue. Still dirt. In ops, a jam can cost lives. Habit now prevents failure later.
How long it take you to clean finish?
20 to 30 minutes, if focused. 10 minutes if PC walking by.
Haha wayang mode.
Wayang is life. Later inspection fail then die.
How do you all memorize so many acronyms?
We drill them daily. COMMS, BATTLECRAFT, SAFETY—everything has a checklist. Repetition makes it automatic under pressure.
Won’t mix them up meh?
Only if you slack. But we revise until it becomes muscle memory. Blur during ops is unacceptable.
What if instructor test randomly?
That’s normal. We’re expected to be ready anytime, anywhere. There’s no ‘later I check’—only ‘ready now’.
Damn intense lah.
Intensity builds reliability. I rather burn out here than blank out later as a leader.
You all really bring dummy rifle even to toilet ah?
Affirmative. Field discipline. Weapon must be within arm’s reach at all times. Even when nature calls, enemy won’t wait.
So how? Rifle outside toilet?
If no buddy, then inside cubicle with me. Muddy floor or not. My rifle follows me everywhere.
That one confirm got rust.
That’s why we clean it properly. Rust is no excuse. Leadership means maintaining your gear, no matter what.
You all really live the doctrine sia.
We don’t just learn doctrine—we become it.
You ever kena scolded until want to cry?
Almost. But as a cadet, I turn that emotion into drive. We’re trained to absorb, not react. Bearing must hold even when inside breaking.
But what if really too much?
Then we talk after hours. Cadet Wing got strong support system. But during training, no breakdown. Only breakthrough.
You all got each other’s back lah.
Always. We may suffer alone but never abandon each other. That’s the OCS way.
Got female cadets in your wing?
Yes, and they hold their own. Equal standards, equal respect. In OCS, leadership has no gender—only performance.
Same tekan also?
Identical. No shortcuts for anyone. We all get judged on same scale—fitness, drills, field, bearing.
Not bad sia.
They raise the bar sometimes. Reminds us never to slack. We train as one, lead as one.
How do you tahan outfield rain?
We embrace it. Rain is part of ops realism. Soak until skin prune, still mission must carry on. Wet uniform, dry mindset.
You don’t even complain?
Got no time to. Complain won't keep me warm. Only movement and morale can.
I confirm grumble like mad sia.
That’s the difference. OCS breaks the old habits, rebuilds leaders.
Every night admin time enough for you meh?
Barely. We compress 2 hours’ worth of tasks into 45 minutes. But that’s leadership—time management under pressure.
So you choose sleep or clean gear?
Gear first. Sleep later. Rifle must be clean, uniform prepped. I rather be tired than unready.
You don’t burn out meh?
We all burn. But we burn together. That’s what forges unity in Cadet Wing.
Got time to call home or not?
Rare, but we get opportunities. Usually during book-out or admin breaks. But when we call, we call with pride.
You tell them the truth or filter?
I tell them I’m learning a lot. No need to worry them with the suffering. What matters is that I’m growing.
They proud of you lah?
I hope so. Every shout, every march—I do it with them in mind. Mission success includes honouring their trust.
Why OCS PT always so hardcore?
Because leading troops requires more than average fitness. PT here conditions us beyond IPPT. We train to lead, not just pass.
Got what kind of PT?
Interval runs, buddy circuits, log PT, endurance marches. Everything designed to test mind and body.
You all still got energy left after that?
Not really. But we move anyway. Garang is about going even when energy finish.
You all still wear helmet when just walking around?
If it’s under tactical condition, yes. Helmet is part of protection and discipline. No such thing as ‘just walking’ in field.
But so heavy sia.
Weight trains resilience. Helmet might save my life one day—discomfort now is small price.
Okay lah, makes sense.
Every item has a reason. In OCS, we learn to respect our gear as much as our role.
Got time to eat during outfield or not?
Only when tactically possible. Sometimes eat in 3 minutes, standing, no spoon. Combat rations teach efficiency.
Nice to eat or not?
After 12 hours of movement? Best thing ever. Even cold rice tastes like buffet when hungry enough.
So y’all never complain lah?
No time to complain. We eat fast, clean up, and continue mission. Survival over comfort.
You all really move off within 1 minute during alarm?
Correct. We drill for rapid deployment. Vest, helmet, rifle, move. Seconds matter in ops—practice makes reflex.
What if halfway wear boot?
No excuse. Either you sleep ready or you move faster. Alarm is test of readiness, not comfort.
Confirm got people blur blur one.
That’s why we train till blur becomes alert. Blur during ops is costly—OCS trains that out of us.
What happens if someone drop rifle in the field?
Immediate correction. Rifle discipline is critical. Weapon is lifeline—if dropped, must report and clean immediately.
Got punishment ah?
Depends. If careless, confirm tekan. If accidental under fatigue, still must recover and reflect. Either way, standard must be restored.
Even dummy rifle also?
Especially dummy rifle. Train like real. Discipline is not about the item—it’s about the habit.
Got any trick to stay awake during long lectures?
Sit upright, take notes, hydrate. When the body wants to sleep, the mind must stay mission-focused. Bearing must never drop.
But sometimes just too shag lah.
Shag is not an excuse. The instructors are watching. I treat every lecture like a mission brief—life may depend on it.
Wah, you really wayang non-stop.
Not wayang—standard. But yes, also wayang. Later PC see you nodding off, confirm kena extra duty.
You all really run everywhere or just for show?
We run because movement equals urgency. Officer Cadets don’t stroll. Running shows intent, purpose, and initiative.
Even just going toilet also?
If in field or time-sensitive, yes. Toilet break or not, enemy won’t wait. Habits formed now save seconds later.
Confirm shin splints lah like that.
Shin splints can recover. Dropped standards cannot.
You all get to choose vocation after OCS?
Negative. We get posted based on SAF’s operational needs. But no matter the posting, officer values must follow.
So cannot say no one ah?
Correct. An officer goes where the fight is. Assignment is a duty, not a preference.
Some kena sai post then how?
Then lead with pride, regardless of role. Leadership is not about glamour—it’s about responsibility.
Can sleep during bus ride back to Wingline?
Affirmative. That’s tactical napping. Once helmet hits seat, knockout. But must be alert once arrival hits.
You don’t scared oversleep then kena?
That’s why I sit upright, boots ready, rifle secured. Sleep one eye open if need to. Always ready to dismount fast.
You all really no rest sia.
Rest is a bonus. Readiness is the standard.
You all really memorise warfighting doctrine ah?
Affirmative. OCS teaches us to internalise doctrine until it becomes instinct. Tactics, ROE, formations—must know cold.
Sound like textbook sia.
Textbook can close. Mind cannot. In chaos, doctrine is anchor.
What if blank out in ops?
Then lives are at stake. That’s why we rehearse until failure is no longer an option.
What if your whole section blur blur during mission?
Then I step up. Cadet or not, leadership has no off switch. We are taught to stabilise, reorganise, and continue mission.
But you also blur how?
Then I fake confidence until clarity returns. In chaos, calmness is command.
Sounds stressful sia.
It is. But better stress now than failure later.
Why you always carry notebook around?
Because memory can fail, but notes won’t. I write down lessons, SOPs, feedback—everything. Officer must learn fast, forget nothing.
Like school sia.
This is school—for leaders. Except mistakes here have real-world impact.
You got time to even read back?
During admin or standby. Every chance to revise is a chance to lead better.
You all got water parade or just drink when want?
We water parade regularly. Hydration is enforced. Wait until thirsty, too late already.
Instructor check your bottle one ah?
Yes. Any excuse to tekan if not full. Water bottle must be as ready as the cadet.
You ever chiong toilet during movement?
Confirmed. But must coordinate. One cadet leave formation, whole section affected. Everything must be accounted for.
Got any reward after commissioning?
The rank is the reward. The privilege to lead, the weight of the bar—that’s what we work for.
No break first ah?
Sometimes short break. But mindset must remain sharp. Commissioning is not the end—it’s the beginning of real responsibility.
Wah, no holiday mood at all.
Holiday is a mindset I switch off. I don’t relax until the people under me are safe and mission is complete.
OCS training really harder than BMT meh?
Without question. BMT builds soldier basics. OCS builds commanders. Physical, mental, emotional—all tested harder.
Got tekan until people dropout?
Yes. Some realise leadership not for them. But those who stay? We carry on, for them and for the men we’ll lead.
Then why you still stay?
Because I believe in leading from the front. The bar means responsibility—and I intend to earn it.
Why your locker always so neat one?
Because discipline starts from the locker. External order reflects internal mindset. Every item must have its place—no excuses.
But no one check everyday what.
Doesn't matter. We prepare like inspection is daily. Leadership means consistency, not convenience.
One time I saw your socks folded like sushi sia.
Correct. Precision in small things builds readiness for big things. Even socks got standard.
Ever kena tekan for someone else’s mistake?
Plenty of times. In OCS, we learn to carry the team. Leadership means owning the outcome, not pointing fingers.
You don’t feel unfair meh?
Unfair is irrelevant. The men we lead will look to us regardless. So we train to absorb, adapt, and move forward.
That’s some next-level mindset.
It’s not mindset—it’s muscle memory now. Trained under pressure, forged by fire.
Do you all get to lead in real missions after OCS?
Affirmative. Upon commissioning, we assume leadership roles in SAF units. What we train here, we apply directly on ground.
That’s a lot of responsibility sia.
Exactly. That's why OCS is so tough. When lives are involved, there’s no room for guesswork.
You scared or not?
Got fear. But trained to control it. Confidence comes from preparation—and that’s what OCS gives us.
What happens if someone break down crying?
Then we support them. Cadet Wing is tough, but it’s also a brotherhood. Breakdown doesn’t mean failure—getting back up does.
So won’t kena scolded?
Depends. If breakdown leads to safety issue, we intervene. But emotionally, we give space. We lead people, not machines.
Respect lah, not what I expected.
OCS trains the body, but also the heart. Compassion is part of command.
How do you all plan section movement so fast?
Drills, SOPs, and hours of practice. In OCS, reaction time is everything. Orders given must be understood and executed without delay.
What if someone blur and move wrong?
Then correct immediately, no drama. Mission comes first. Debrief later, execute now.
Damn high tempo sia.
Because war is high tempo. OCS is just the rehearsal.
How do you handle feedback from instructors?
With humility. Feedback is fuel. Even if the tone is harsh, the message builds us. Ego got no place in OCS.
Some instructors very fierce sia.
Correct. But they fierce because they care. Their job is to prepare us for worse things than shouting.
So you just nod and accept?
Nod, reflect, apply. Grow every day or fall behind. That’s the rule here.
Any chance to lead in peacetime ops as cadets?
Some cadets assist in peacetime deployments—like security ops or exercises. But full command comes after commissioning.
So mostly training now?
Yes, but realistic and intense. We train as if every scenario is live. That way, real ops don’t catch us off guard.
Smart move.
Preparation over improvisation. That’s the OCS difference.
Got anyone fail OCS?
Yes. Some get recourse, some out-processed. OCS isn’t about passing everyone—it’s about preparing the right ones.
Fail because of fitness or what?
Could be fitness, conduct, or inability to lead. Instructors watch everything. Commissioning is earned, never given.
Pressure sia.
Correct. But pressure reveals who’s ready. That’s the whole point.
Got any female instructors?
Yes, and they’re just as strict—sometimes stricter. Respect given regardless of rank or gender. Standard is universal.
You all scared of them or not?
We respect them. Fear is not the word—more like ‘better don’t mess up’ energy.
Sounds intense.
Every instructor represents the SAF standard. Doesn’t matter male or female—only discipline.
What happens if someone gets injured during field camp?
We activate medics and follow CASEVAC SOP. Safety always comes first. The rest continue mission unless told otherwise.
So you don’t stop training ah?
Only if mission requires. Otherwise, we adapt and continue. Field realism includes unpredictability.
The rest won’t be affected meh?
We feel it, but we move. As officers, we must balance empathy with mission focus.
How fast must you react during contact drills?
Within seconds. Return fire, seek cover, issue orders. Delay means mission fail. We rehearse until response is instinct.
You don’t even think first?
Thinking still happens—but fast. We train so hard that reaction becomes calculated reflex.
You all really robots sia.
Not robots—just conditioned leaders. In chaos, clarity must come from the commander.
Got time to pray or not during training?
If training allows and safety permits, yes. Spiritual discipline is respected. But must coordinate and not disrupt ops.
So like no problem one lah?
Correct. Just need to inform commanders early. Respect works both ways—faith and field must co-exist.
That’s quite fair sia.
In OCS, we uphold values—including respect for religion. But mission still comes first.
OCS got any competition between wings?
Yes, friendly rivalry. We compete in drills, PT, proficiency. Builds pride and pushes performance. But end of day, we all Officer Cadet School.
Got punishments for losing?
Not punishment—just extra motivation. Losing wing usually kena morale talks or more PT. All part of character building.
Steady lah. You all take it quite seriously huh.
Everything we do is serious. Even competition reflects leadership spirit.
You ever forget your rank when you in civvies?
Sometimes I forget others can't see it. But rank is mindset—not just bar. Civvies or not, I carry myself like a cadet.
You still walk fast outside also?
Confirm. Movement with purpose is muscle memory now. Even at MRT I walk like got mission.
Haha no off switch for you sia.
OCS trains us to lead in and out of uniform. That’s the goal.
Do instructors scold you if you smile too much?
If smiling at wrong time, yes. Must read the situation. Parade square is not for giggles—bearing must hold.
So you serious face 24/7?
Not 24/7, but when it matters. Smile during breaks, not during drill. Professionalism comes first.
Hard to keep straight face leh.
That's why we train. Self-control is leadership 101.
You ever kena tekan for standing wrong?
Yes. Feet not 45 degrees, arms not straight—boom, whole section tekan. Posture reflects mindset.
Wah serious until like that ah.
Serious because details matter. If I slack in drill, I slack in ops. Bearing must be flawless.
You all really next-level disciplined.
OCS doesn’t just build officers—it builds standards.
You all ever joke with instructors or not?
Only when they open the door. Otherwise, maintain respect and bearing. We’re cadets—they're commanders.
So not totally fierce lah?
They’re firm, not fierce. Once trust is earned, can joke a bit—but always within boundary.
I thought confirm kena if talk back.
Talk back, yes. But respectful banter? Sometimes allowed. Depends on context and timing.
What if you lose something important during outfield?
Immediate report, initiate search. Accountability is key. Missing item = leadership failure. Doesn’t matter how small.
Even if it’s just a glove?
Yes. One glove becomes one man’s weakness in the field. We train to be 100% accountable at all times.
So confirm tekan lah.
If preventable, yes. But it’s about learning. The pain now prevents greater loss later.
You ever fall asleep while standing?
Once or twice. Sleep debt builds. But we train to fight it. Standby means alert—not sway like tree in wind.
What happen if instructor sees?
Immediate correction. Could be knock-it-down, could be extra duty. But always a lesson in alertness.
Wah cannot even blink too long.
Blink fast, stand sharp. Bearing doesn’t rest.
How you all tahan parade rehearsal under the sun?
Hydrate, lock knees, deep focus. Parade rehearsal is about discipline in discomfort. No fidgeting, no wiping sweat.
What if got mozzie bite?
Endure. Scratch later. Moment you move, whole row looks sloppy. Bearing over itch.
You got sunburn before or not?
Got. But parade doesn’t pause for UV rays. Standard must hold—rain or shine.
You all really recite SAF core values every day?
Affirmative. We recite them before meals, during parades, sometimes even during tekan. Repetition makes it stick—values must be lived, not memorised.
Won’t get bored meh?
Never. Every time we say it, it reminds us why we wear the green. Loyalty, discipline, professionalism—all must become habit.
So if forget one you kena?
Confirm. But more than kena—we reflect. Values are our compass. Cannot afford to misplace it.
What’s the worst tekan you kena before?
Endless leopard crawl through mud while shouting values. Muscles cramp, uniform soaked, but still must maintain bearing.
For what reason sia?
Miscommunication during section movement. Leader didn’t clarify, team got lost. In OCS, mistakes equal lessons.
You angry or not?
No time to be angry. Only time to improve. Every tekan is a chance to become better.
Got time to celebrate birthdays in OCS?
Rarely. But if schedule permits, we do something small—maybe a slice of cake, quick cheer. Then straight back to mission.
Sounds quite sad leh.
Not sad—purposeful. We sacrifice comfort for commitment. Commissioning is the real celebration.
Wah, your whole wing so garang.
We train together, suffer together, lead together. Brotherhood is the best gift here.
How do you know you’re ready to lead men?
When I stop thinking about myself and start thinking for the platoon. Leadership is responsibility, not rank.
But what if still feel unsure?
Then train harder. Doubt disappears with preparation. Confidence is earned through hardship.
Damn deep sia.
In OCS, we don’t just build officers. We build character.
You all talk about doctrine a lot ah?
All the time. Doctrine is our foundation. Without it, tactics got no structure. Every plan must align with doctrine.
But don’t it change sometimes?
Correct. That’s why we learn principles, not just words. Leaders adapt doctrine to terrain, not copy blindly.
Wah, you all sound like commanders already.
That’s the point. OCS prepares us for tomorrow’s war, not yesterday’s notes.
What’s the hardest part of being a cadet?
Balancing fatigue with leadership. Must stay sharp, even when mentally drained. Others can fade—we cannot.
So how you cope?
Routine, support, and purpose. My wing, my buddy, my mission—they keep me going when energy finish.
Sounds brutal.
It is. But brutal builds backbone. And backbone is what officers need most.
Got any cadets drop out halfway?
Yes. Some realise this path not for them. It’s not shameful—better to be honest than to fake leadership.
So no tekan if drop?
No tekan for that. But we debrief and reflect. Everyone must own their decision. OCS is voluntary—but serious.
Respect that man.
OCS doesn’t force leaders—it forges them.
Got time to do laundry during training?
During admin time, yes. But sometimes must hand wash at 2300hrs after debrief. Hygiene still important even if shag.
You dry uniform how?
Fan, hanger, or just hope it dries overnight. Wet or not, next day still wear. We don’t pause for comfort.
Confirm got jungle smell.
Jungle smell is part of life. Bearing still must be fresh.
Can you volunteer to be IC?
Yes. Initiative is encouraged. But once you volunteer, you must deliver. IC isn’t just title—it’s responsibility.
What if screw up as IC?
Then own up, learn, and bounce back. OCS allows failure—what matters is recovery.
So they don’t expect perfect IC?
No one’s perfect. But commitment, effort, and growth? That one must be 100%.
How many sets of uniform you all rotate?
Usually 2 to 3. One on body, one drying, one standby. But if rain nonstop, all three wet also still wear.
Why not get more?
Because training teaches resilience, not reliance. If can’t function with 2 sets, how to survive with 1 in ops?
That one confirm chao turtle smell.
Smell can scrub. Leadership must stay clean no matter what.
Ever kena tekan because someone didn’t shave?
Yes. Clean shave is non-negotiable. One cadet forget, whole section feel the heat. Attention to detail is key.
But just facial hair only what.
If we miss the small things, we miss the big ones later. Discipline is not selective.
Wah you all really no leeway.
Because in leadership, there’s no room for slack. Even the razor plays a part.
How do you stay so motivated every day?
Remind myself why I’m here. To lead, to protect, to earn the bar. Even on low days, purpose must stay high.
What if one day just feel like giving up?
Then I look at my section. I carry on for them. Mission first, self later.
Real soldier mindset sia.
Not just soldier—leader. That’s what OCS drills into us.
What’s the earliest you’ve had to wake up?
0330 hrs. Prep for movement, equipment check, full kit, all before first light. Still must move fast and sharp.
You all human or not sia.
Barely. But commitment makes it possible. We lead tired, so that our men don’t have to.
Sleep is luxury in OCS huh.
Exactly. Rest when the mission is done. Not before.
What if it’s raining during live firing?
We adapt. Unless unsafe, training continues. Rain teaches control under pressure. Weapon must still function. So must we.
Hard to even see the target like that.
True. But ops won’t wait for clear skies. Accuracy under stress is part of leadership training.
Not easy sia.
Nothing in OCS is. That’s why it works.
Can cadets fall out during route march?
Only if medically necessary. Otherwise, we press on. Falling out affects morale and momentum.
But body got limit right?
Yes. But OCS pushes that limit safely. Instructors observe closely. Still, mindset must be ‘push until told to stop’.
Wah mental game sia.
Correct. Physical strength ends. Mental strength carries.
You all really move out at 0200 before ah?
Affirmative. Night movement trains navigation, coordination, and silence. Ops don’t happen only during daylight.
You don’t knock into tree or what?
Sometimes yes. But that’s why we train. Night ops build trust and awareness. Even when visibility is zero.
Steady lah.
Steady because of training. Every step in darkness sharpens leadership.
Ever had to move casualty during mission?
Yes. Simulated casualty evac under fire drill. One man down, rest adjust. Mission adapts to protect life and complete task.
That one must be damn heavy.
Correct. But adrenaline and urgency take over. We train to lift more than weight—we lift responsibility.
Respect bro.
Appreciate it. Just doing what we’re trained for.
How you all manage navigation during outfield?
Maps, bearings, resection—every cadet trains hard on nav. One wrong grid can mess the whole mission. Accuracy is non-negotiable.
What if terrain totally different from map?
Then adjust using features, pace count, and section feedback. Leadership means adapting, not panicking.
Got lost before?
Yes. But recovered. Because in OCS, we don’t stay lost—we lead back to the route.
How do you communicate during fire movement?
Hand signals, shouts, section SOPs. Everything drilled till auto. Noise discipline still applies—even under fire.
Got time to even think what to signal meh?
That’s why we drill. No time to think—only react right. Wrong signal = wrong move = mission risk.
Chim sia.
Chim because life is on the line. Leadership is clarity under chaos.
Got time to write reflection in OCS?
Yes, during admin nights or after major training. Reflection helps reinforce lessons. Leadership requires self-awareness.
But you all not too tired to think meh?
Tired, but still write. Even 5 lines better than nothing. Reflection now prevents repeated mistakes later.
Makes sense.
In OCS, improvement is a daily exercise. Reflection is part of the process.
Can fall asleep during mission brief or not?
Cannot. Mission brief is sacred. One missed detail can derail the whole op. Bearing must hold—no matter how shag.
Even if midnight also must focus?
Especially if midnight. Fatigue cannot affect comprehension. Leadership demands alertness, 24/7.
You all really no off switch.
Correct. Until the mission ends, the mindset stays on.
How long is the longest outfield you kena?
10 days. Continuous missions, limited sleep, full gear. By the end, only discipline kept us moving.
You don’t lose track of time meh?
Lost track of date, not purpose. Every day was just: move, lead, survive.
Sounds crazy.
Crazy builds character. That’s what OCS is for.
You all got time to use phone during course?
Only during book-out or admin breaks. Otherwise, phones are out of sight. Focus is 100% on training.
What if emergency?
We inform instructors or PC. Chain of command is in place. Discipline doesn’t mean cut off from reality.
Okay lah, fair enough.
Correct. OCS teaches balance—mission first, but still human.
You ever lead section during live firing?
Yes. It’s one of the most intense experiences. Every order must be clear. No room for hesitation with live rounds.
You nervous or not?
Yes. But I channeled it into focus. Leadership is performing under pressure.
Confirm adrenaline maxed out.
Maxed out but managed. That’s what training prepares us for.
You all ever kena lost compass direction?
Yes, especially in dense terrain. But training kicks in. Backtrack, reorient, and keep calm.
Won’t kena scolded meh?
Kena—but learn. Navigation errors happen. The key is how fast you recover, not how loud you panic.
Okay lah, fair point.
OCS is about recovery under pressure. That’s leadership in action.
What if you fall sick during outfield?
Report to instructors, let MO assess. But if not serious, we press on. Minor flu? Still mission go.
Wah confirm suffer.
Correct. But OCS trains us to lead while uncomfortable. Sick doesn’t mean stop—unless safety is at risk.
That’s tough bro.
Tough now builds strong leaders later.
What happens if you lose your ID tag?
Immediate report. ID tag is accountability. Losing it reflects poorly on discipline—confirm kena after-action review.
Even if drop during movement?
Still must account. We don’t excuse by circumstance—we recover, reflect, and tighten our procedures.
Strict sia.
Strict because one small item can become one big issue in ops.
How do you balance between shouting and giving clear orders?
Shouting must have purpose. I project voice, not scream blindly. Cadence, clarity, confidence—that’s the triad.
What if men cannot hear?
Then I adapt. Use hand signals, reposition, repeat if needed. Leading is about being understood—not just loud.
Makes sense.
In chaos, calm communication saves lives. That’s officer standard.
Can cadets ask questions during mission briefs?
Yes, and we’re encouraged to. Clarify before execution. But must be relevant and sharp—no time for blur queries.
What if kena laughed at?
Better to be laughed at now than fail later. OCS culture: ask, learn, lead.
Good mindset sia.
Correct. Leadership starts with humility to ask.
What’s the first thing you’ll do after commissioning?
Thank my section and instructors. Then reset my focus. Commissioning is not the end—it’s Day 1 of real leadership.
No big party ah?
Maybe small one with family. But in my head? Already planning how to lead my new unit.
You really live and breathe this officer life.
Because lives will depend on me. And that’s not something I take lightly.
